questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with sudden onset hearing loss in the right ear following a viral infection. She also complains of tinnitus and imbalance. Pure tone audiometry confirms profound sensorineural hearing loss in the affected ear, with normal hearing on the opposite side. During tuning fork tests, Rinne test appears negative on the affected side and Weber lateralizes to the normal ear. What is the most appropriate interpretation of this Rinne test result?

choices.text: Surgical excision of cerebellopontine angle tumor

questions.text: An audiogram of a 40-year-old patient shows sensorineural hearing loss predominantly affecting low frequencies with a rising (ascending) curve pattern as shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management for this patient?

A 7-year-old child presents with recurrent complaints of ear blockage and mild hearing loss for 6 months. There is no ear discharge or pain. On otoscopy, the tympanic membrane appears dull, retracted with a fluid level seen behind it. Tympanometry shows a flat (Type B) curve. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management for this patient?

choices.text: Conservative medical therapy with topical antibiotics and steroids

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents with persistent foul-smelling ear discharge and progressive hearing loss for 1 year. Otoscopy shows a posterosuperior marginal perforation with granulation tissue and keratin debris. CT temporal bone reveals erosion of the lateral semicircular canal. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient?

The maneuver shown in the image below is used in the management of benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) by dislodging otoliths from the posterior semicircular canal through rapid head and body movements. Identify the maneuver:

choices.text: 1. Microphone, 2. Transmitter, 3. Receiver–Stimulator, 4. Reference electrode, 5. Intracochlear electrode
1. Transmitter, 2. Microphone, 3. Receiver–Stimulator, 4. Intracochlear electrode, 5. Reference electrode
1. Receiver–Stimulator, 2. Transmitter, 3. Microphone, 4. Reference electrode, 5. Intracochlear electrode
1. Microphone, 2. Receiver–Stimulator, 3. Transmitter, 4. Intracochlear electrode, 5. Reference electrode

questions.text: Image of a cochlear implant is shown below. Select the correct option that labelled all parts correctly:
questions.solution: Ans. A) 1. Microphone, 2. Transmitter, 3. Receiver–Stimulator, 4. Reference electrode, 5. Intracochlear electrode

questions.text: A CT scan of the paranasal sinuses (PNS) shows a pneumatized middle turbinate (as seen in the image below). Which of the following is the correct diagnosis?

A 55-year-old hypertensive man presents to the emergency department with profuse bleeding from the right nostril for the past 2 hours. He reports a history of recurrent mild nosebleeds but has never required hospitalization. On examination, there is no active anterior bleeding point visible in Little’s area, and blood is trickling into the oropharynx. His BP is 170/100 mmHg. What is the next best step in management after initial first-aid measures?

A 26-year-old woman presents with recurrent bouts of sneezing, watery nasal discharge, nasal obstruction, and itching for the past 3 years. Her symptoms worsen in the early morning and during exposure to dust and cold air. She denies any history of asthma or atopy. Skin prick test is negative, and serum IgE levels are normal. Nasal smear shows numerous eosinophils. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: MRI of paranasal sinuses and orbit
Nasal endoscopy with biopsy for KOH mount

questions.text: A 48-year-old post-COVID male with uncontrolled diabetes mellitus presents with facial pain, nasal obstruction, blackish nasal discharge, and swelling around the left eye. On examination, there is black eschar over the middle turbinate and palate, and the patient complains of blurring of vision. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial investigation to assess the extent of disease and orbital involvement?
questions.solution: Ans. B) MRI of paranasal sinuses and orbit

choices.text: Beta-2 transferrin assay of nasal fluid
High-resolution CT scan of paranasal sinuses

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents with clear watery nasal discharge from the right nostril for 3 weeks following a road-traffic accident. The discharge increases on bending forward and decreases on lying down. It is not associated with sneezing or itching. On examination, no mass or inflammation is seen in the nasal cavity. Which of the following investigations is most specific for confirming CSF rhinorrhea?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Beta-2 transferrin assay of nasal fluid

questions.text: During thyroid surgery, a surgeon accidentally injures a branch of the vagus nerve that supplies all intrinsic muscles of the larynx except one. Which of the following muscles is spared and remains functional?

choices.text: External branch of superior laryngeal nerve
Internal branch of superior laryngeal nerve

questions.text: A patient presents with hoarseness of voice and breathiness following thyroid surgery. Laryngoscopy reveals one vocal cord fixed in the paramedian position while the other moves normally. Which of the following nerves is most likely injured?

A 40-year-old male professional teacher presents with hoarseness of voice for the past 3 months. He denies pain or difficulty in swallowing. He is a chronic smoker and frequently raises his voice while teaching. Laryngoscopic image is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Biopsy of the mass to confirm diagnosis
Pre-operative angiographic embolization followed by surgical excision
External beam radiotherapy as first-line treatment

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents with recurrent episodes of profuse epistaxis and progressive nasal obstruction for 6 months. On examination, a reddish mass is seen filling the nasopharynx, which bleeds on touch. CT scan shows a soft-tissue mass in the nasopharynx extending into the pterygopalatine fossa and infratemporal fossa with widening of the sphenopalatine foramen. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Pre-operative angiographic embolization followed by surgical excision

choices.text: Repeat Nd:YAG laser peripheral iridotomy at a different site
Intravenous mannitol with topical pilocarpine 2% immediately
Intravenous mannitol with topical atropine 1% followed by laser peripheral iridoplasty

questions.text: A 52-year-old hypermetropic female, status post bilateral prophylactic laser peripheral iridotomy 6 months ago, presents with 4-hour history of right eye pain, blurred vision, and vomiting. Exam shows ciliary congestion, corneal edema, mid-dilated pupil, patent iridotomy, and IOP 48 mmHg. Ultrasound biomicroscopy reveals anterior ciliary processes with flat iris plane and normal axial anterior chamber depth. What is the most appropriate immediate management?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Intravenous mannitol with topical atropine 1% and laser peripheral iridoplasty

questions.text: A 4-year-old child born at 32 weeks of gestation with birth weight of 1800 grams is being screened for retinopathy of prematurity (ROP). When should the first screening examination be performed?
questions.solution: Ans. B) At 4 weeks postnatal age

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient who underwent penetrating keratoplasty 8 months ago for advanced keratoconus presents with sudden visual loss in the grafted eye. Slit-lamp examination shows a linear demarcation advancing from the graft periphery toward the center, associated with keratic precipitates and corneal edema. The patient reports no pain or photophobia. Which clinical sign most specifically indicates the type of graft rejection in this case?

choices.text: Pretectal area in the dorsal midbrain
Ciliary ganglion with postganglionic parasympathetic denervation
Optic tract causing afferent pathway defect

questions.text: A 58-year-old male with a history of untreated syphilis presents with bilateral small, irregular pupils that constrict briskly during accommodation but show absent direct and consensual light reflexes. On attempted pupillary dilatation with mydriatics, minimal response is observed. Which of the following best describes the anatomical site of lesion responsible for this pupillary abnormality?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Pretectal area in the dorsal midbrain

questions.text: A 35-year-old emmetropic patient presents with a near point of 14 cm. After detailed examination, you find that the patient can focus clearly from infinity down to 14 cm. A few months later, the same patient returns complaining of difficulty with near work. On examination, the near point has receded to 25 cm while the far point remains at infinity. What is the change in amplitude of accommodation between the two visits?

choices.text: Floor stains with fluorescein, margins stain with rose bengal; topical acyclovir and avoid steroids
Margins stain with fluorescein, floor stains with rose bengal; topical steroids accelerate healing
Floor stains with rose bengal only; treatment requires only lubricants as no active virus present
Entire lesion stains uniformly with both dyes; combination antiviral-steroid therapy indicated

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with recurrent unilateral eye pain, redness, and photophobia. On slit-lamp examination with fluorescein staining, the corneal lesion shown in the image is observed. Corneal aesthesiometry reveals markedly reduced sensation. Rose bengal staining shows uptake at the lesion margins. Which statement about this condition is most accurate regarding its staining characteristics and management?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Floor stains with fluorescein, margins stain with rose bengal; topical acyclovir and avoid steroids

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient presents with a painless nodular swelling on the upper eyelid. During surgical excision, the surgeon needs to identify the proper plane for dissection. The image below shows a cross-sectional anatomy of the eyelid. Which layer, marked in red in the diagram, contains the meibomian glands and provides the structural framework to the eyelid?

choices.text: Rupture of Descemet's membrane causing aqueous influx and stromal hydration
Acute endothelial decompensation due to reduced endothelial cell count
Spontaneous corneal perforation with iris prolapse requiring urgent surgery
Acute infectious keratitis secondary to chronic contact lens use

questions.text: A 24-year-old known case of keratoconus presents with sudden onset severe pain, photophobia, and marked decrease in vision. Slit-lamp examination reveals diffuse corneal edema and opacification in the affected eye. What is the underlying pathological mechanism responsible for this acute presentation?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Rupture of Descemet's membrane causing aqueous influx and stromal hydration

choices.text: Attempt to retrieve the nucleus with lens loop through the main incision
Complete anterior vitrectomy and cortical cleanup, refer to vitreoretinal surgeon
Convert to intracapsular cataract extraction and remove the nucleus
Extend the incision and deliver the nucleus with vectis

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient undergoes manual SICS for mature senile cataract. During surgery, while performing hydrodissection, the surgeon notices sudden deepening of the anterior chamber with loss of red reflex. The nucleus that was being mobilized is no longer visible in the anterior segment. Intraoperatively, what is the most appropriate immediate management?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Complete anterior vitrectomy and cortical cleanup, refer to vitreoretinal surgeon

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with recurrent unilateral eye pain, redness, and photophobia. Examination shows circumciliary congestion, fine stellate keratic precipitates diffusely over the cornea, with the affected eye lighter in colour, elevated IOP (28 mmHg), absence of posterior synechiae, and spontaneous hyphema during paracentesis. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Primary prevention; highly cost-effective in all populations
Secondary prevention; cost-effective only in high-prevalence areas
Primary prevention; cost-effective mainly in high-prevalence populations

questions.text: A community health program implements administration of iron and folic acid tablets to all adolescent girls in schools regardless of their hemoglobin levels to prevent iron deficiency anemia. This intervention is being evaluated for its cost-effectiveness compared to screening-based targeted supplementation. What level of prevention does this intervention represent, and what is typically its cost-effectiveness profile?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Primary prevention; cost-effective mainly in high-prevalence populations

questions.text: A researcher wants to investigate whether prolonged exposure to indoor air pollution from biomass fuel cooking is associated with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) in rural women aged 40-60 years. The study needs to be completed within 2 years with limited funding, and the prevalence of COPD in this population is approximately 8%. Which epidemiological study design would be most appropriate for this research question?

A screening test for cervical cancer was conducted on 1000 women. The results showed that 80 women tested positive, out of which 60 actually had cervical cancer. Among the 920 women who tested negative, 40 actually had cervical cancer. What is the sensitivity and specificity of this screening test?

choices.text: Classify as no dehydration and advise home-based ORS therapy with zinc supplementation
Classify as some dehydration and give ORS 75 ml/kg over 4 hours at the health facility
Classify as severe dehydration and start IV fluids 100 ml/kg over 3 hours immediately
Classify as some dehydration and refer urgently to higher center for IV fluid management

questions.text: A 12-month-old child is brought to the primary health center with a 3-day history of loose stools (8-10 episodes/day) and vomiting (4-5 episodes/day). On examination, the child is irritable, has sunken eyes, skin pinch goes back slowly (2 seconds), and the mother reports decreased urine output. The child weighs 8 kg and appears lethargic but drinks eagerly when offered water. According to IMNCI guidelines, what is the next best step in management?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Classify as some dehydration and give ORS 75 ml/kg over 4 hours at the health facility

choices.text: Relative risk = 8.0; There is 8 times higher risk of acute kidney injury in exposed children
Relative risk = 5.3; There is 5.3 times higher risk of acute kidney injury in exposed children
Relative risk = 0.4; There is 60% lower risk of acute kidney injury in exposed children
Relative risk = 2.67; There is 2.67 times higher risk of acute kidney injury in exposed children

questions.text: During an outbreak investigation of acute kidney injury in children, epidemiologists found that among 200 children who consumed contaminated cough syrup, 80 developed acute kidney injury. Among 300 children who did not consume the contaminated cough syrup, 15 developed acute kidney injury. What is the relative risk of developing acute kidney injury among children who consumed contaminated cough syrup compared to those who did not, and how should this be interpreted?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Relative risk = 8.0; There is 8 times higher risk of acute kidney injury in exposed children

choices.text: ABC analysis classifies Category A items as high-value items requiring tight control and frequent monitoring
Economic Order Quantity (EOQ) model helps determine the optimal order quantity that minimizes total inventory costs
Safety stock levels should be maintained higher for Category C items due to their critical nature
Just-in-Time (JIT) inventory system reduces holding costs but requires reliable supplier relationships

questions.text: All of the following statements regarding inventory control systems in healthcare are correct except:
questions.solution: Ans. C) Safety stock levels should be maintained higher for Category C items due to their critical nature

choices.text: Screening and Basic management of Mental health ailment
Care for Common Ophthalmic and ENT problems
Bi-weekly super-specialist care in Cardiology and Endocrinology

questions.text: Under the Ayushman Bharat Health and Wellness Centre initiative, the expanded package of services at Ayushman Arogya Mandir includes all of the following except:
questions.solution: Ans. D) Bi-weekly super-specialist care in Cardiology and Endocrinology

choices.text: The event constitutes a public health risk to other States through international spread AND potentially requires a coordinated international response
The event has caused more than 1000 deaths in the affected country within 30 days of onset
The event involves a pathogen with pandemic potential as listed in WHO's priority pathogen list
The event has spread to at least 3 countries across 2 different WHO regions

questions.text: According to the International Health Regulations (2005), which of the following criteria must be met for the WHO Director-General to declare a Public Health Emergency of International Concern (PHEIC)?
questions.solution: Ans. A) The event constitutes a public health risk to other States through international spread AND potentially requires a coordinated international response

choices.text: Conduct vulnerability assessment and hazard mapping

questions.text: A district health officer is reviewing the disaster management preparedness following recent flash floods in a rural area. The immediate response phase has been completed with rescue operations and emergency medical care. The community now requires restoration of basic health services and temporary shelter arrangements. What would be the next best step in the disaster management cycle?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Initiate recovery and rehabilitation activities

choices.text: 1 Community Health Officer (CHO) + 1 ANM + 1 ASHA
1 Community Health Officer (CHO) + 1 ANM + 1 MPW

questions.text: According to IPHS 2022 guidelines, what is the minimum staffing pattern required for a Health and Wellness Center- Sub-Health center serving a population of 6000 in the plains area?
questions.solution: Ans. D) 1 Community Health Officer (CHO) + 1 ANM + 1 MPW

choices.text: Treatment is provided free of cost for BPL patients only
Treatment is provided free of cost for all patients irrespective of economic status
Treatment cost is subsidized by 50% for BPL patients
Treatment is free only for the first 2 months of intensive phase

questions.text: A 35-year-old male diagnosed with pulmonary tuberculosis belongs to Below Poverty Line (BPL) category. He is concerned about the treatment cost under the National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP). What should be told to the patient regarding the cost of anti-tuberculosis treatment under NTEP?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Treatment is provided free of cost for all patients irrespective of economic status

questions.text: A 15-month-old child presents to a Primary Health Centre with incomplete vaccination status. The child has received BCG at birth, OPV-0 at birth, Pentavalent-1 at 6 weeks, OPV-1 at 6 weeks, and Rotavirus-1 at 6 weeks. No further vaccines were given due to family migration. The mother is concerned about catch-up vaccination. According to current immunization guidelines, what is the MINIMUM number of visits required to complete the primary immunization schedule for this child, excluding the measles vaccines?

choices.text: Stage 1 - High birth rate and high death rate
Stage 2 - High birth rate and declining death rate
Stage 3 - Declining birth rate and low death rate
Stage 4 - Low birth rate and low death rate

questions.text: The demographic transition model describes the transition from high birth and death rates to low birth and death rates as a country develops economically. In which stage of the demographic transition model does a population experience the maximum growth rate?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Stage 2 - High birth rate and declining death rate

choices.text: Insert Copper-T 380A immediately as it provides long-term contraception
Treat presumptive pelvic inflammatory disease first, then insert IUD after completion of treatment
Start combined oral contraceptive pills and reassess after 3 months
Insert Levonorgestrel-releasing IUD as it has anti-inflammatory properties

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with regular menstrual cycles visits the family planning clinic requesting contraception. She mentions having multiple sexual partners and desires a highly effective, long-acting reversible contraceptive method. On examination, she has mild cervical tenderness and mucopurulent cervical discharge. Her pregnancy test is negative. What is the most appropriate immediate management?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Treat presumptive pelvic inflammatory disease first, then insert IUD after completion of treatment

choices.text: Items contaminated with cytotoxic drugs along with glass or plastic ampoules
Human anatomical waste from surgical specimens

questions.text: According to Bio Medical Waste Management Rules 2016, which of the following waste items should not be discarded in the yellow bin?
Identify the heart chamber marked in the given CT image:
Which of the following investigations does not use ionizing radiation?
A patient with history of TB presents with hemoptysis. X-ray is shown. What is the likely diagnosis?
In a male child having recurrent urinary problems, an imaging as done was shown. What is the management?

An ultrasound of a 24-year-old woman shows an endometrium with a classic trilaminar appearance, as seen in the image provided. Which phase of the menstrual cycle does this ultrasound image most likely represent?
All of these are causes of bilious vomiting in a neonate at birth except:

A 32-year-old woman presents to AIIMS OPD with complaints of oligomenorrhea for the past six months. She has a history of two previous pregnancies, both of which resulted in miscarriages. She underwent a HSG which is shown here. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 42-year-old woman presents with a severe, sudden-onset, throbbing headache and double vision for the past 30 minutes. She has a history of migraine and reports frequent headaches. She has not had her period for several months. On examination, her blood pressure is 95/61 mm Hg, and visual field testing reveals decreased visual acuity and loss of peripheral vision in both eyes. MRI of brain is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
What is the most likely cause of the condition depicted in the HRCT below?
What is the likely diagnosis based on the images shown?
